FOUR
BETTER BROADCASTS NEWS LETTER
OCTOBER 1, 1953
Some TV Standards
In gathering information for his “Tele¬
vision and Education in the United States,”
Dr. Charles A. Siepmann asked television
networks what they mean by education and
what their relation is to it. He got this
response from NBC, to quote a small part of
it from the book:
Education may be taken to mean "the
total process by which the individual is
brought toward informed adjustment to his
society . . . The materials of reality, of cur¬
rent affairs, history, the sciences, the hu¬
manities, are inexhaustible and fascinating.
The people of our country have an appetite
for such materials beyond our ability to
predict; ... We feel that . . . our total
programme output on all hours of the day,
on all days of the week, over the years,
must serve the ends of education in the
broad sense indicated by our working de¬
finition . . . Negatively, we are convinced
that no programme may be excused for
contributing to the vulgarization of our
viewers, and we have set up stringent pro¬
cedures to examine, in advance of broad¬
casts, not only scripts but also costuming,
movement and characterization which might
offend the home and audience.
“We are working under a long term and
well considered plan to involve every pro¬
gramme we have in the task of enlighten¬
ment. This means that we count as partners
in the task advertisers, advertising agencies,
talent agencies, stars, writers, producers,
directors and all engaged in the process of
production.”
This is a remarkable statement of policy.
Any network or station that announces such
a policy should have the active help of the
public in living up to it. A letter of appre¬
ciation for a definite program of high qual¬
ity from individuals would help maintain
high quality, especially if the letter were
heartwarmingly specific about why the
program was fine. Telling friends about its
high points will help to build an audience
for it, and so keep it on the air. If a letter
is to state that some phases of a program
might be improved, it would be well to begin
with a compliment on the good points.
Dr. Siepmann is Chairman of the Com¬
munications Department of New York Uni¬
versity. The book (125 pp., $1.00) was
recently published by UNESCO, and it is
available from the Columbia University
Press.
Educational Television
The Resolutions adopted at Minneapolis
for 1953-1954 state that the American Coun¬
cil for Better Broadcasts will “work to ob¬
tain and support education television sta¬
tions—and by its efforts and encouragement
assist to make educational television pro¬
grams of compelling interest and value.”
As we work in our different areas, one
good source of advice will be the Joint
Helps in
Have you heard several commentators on
the same day talking about the same news?
A year ago De Alton Neher recorded such
excerpts on tape (25 minutes). It is an ex¬
cellent spring board for discussion. It can
be had for the cost of tape, dubbing, and
sending. But order well in advance.
“The Listener Speaks Again,” 2,000
words, 1953. (10c) suggests standards for
programs. It was prepared by the San
Francisco Branch of the AAUW, 1840
Committee on Educational Televson, 1758
Massachusetts Avenue, N.W., Washing¬
ton 6, D.C. It also sometmes sends out
speakers to meetings on Educational TV.
Another source of help is the National
Citizens’ Committee for Educational Tele¬
vision, Ring Building, Washington 6, D.C.
It has a 16mm. 25-minute film, “New Vision
for Television.” If you want to show it,
write for it well in advance. It is popular.
Your name on its mailing list will bring
you its monthly News Bulletin, which car¬
ries encouraging stories like these:
WILMETTE
In Wilmette, a suburb of Chicago, three
women, led by Mrs. Leighton Cooney, head¬
ed a drive to raise money for Chicago’s
Channel 11. They roused the whole com¬
munity. One man offered the use of his
printing press. Another gave paper. A
clergyman offered the use of the mime¬
ograph. Two publicity writers offered their
services. Children in a parochial school
wrote a play contrasting present TV with
what they hoped educational TV would be.
One leader said: “This pioneering was
based on faith in the leadership of the uni¬
versities, colleges, museums and cultural in¬
stitutions, and faith that within these in¬
stitutions were knowledges, skills, and un¬
derstanding which might now be shared
with many people.”
SEATTLE
In Seattle the owner of a commercial TV
station Mrs. A. Scott Bullitt, sparked edu¬
cational television. First she scheduled suc¬
cessful educational programs on KING-TV.
After two years, she said, “We realize from
our experience that there are natural limit¬
ations to the ability of a commercial-station
to serve fully and adequately the educa¬
tional requirements of a community.”
She gave the Citizens’ Committee for
Educational TV, television equipment val¬
ued at $182,000. The fund-raising cam¬
paign went forward. Seattle has now made
application for an educational television
channel.
NEW ORLEANS
In New Orleans, where a commercial
company asked the FCC to set aside the
reservation for educational use of a chan¬
nel and open it to commercial use, citizens
were roused. They asked the FCC to deny
the request, an action which it has now
taken.
The Federal Communications
Commission
The FCC has its problems. It consists of
seven commissioners with a staff too small
for the work that needs to be accomplished.
Congress established it, told it to grant li¬
censes to stations that would “operate in
the public interest, convenience, and neces¬
sity,” but has never given it a large enough
staff to review stations’ past performance
to see whether they kept their promises to
operate in the public interest.
The public should consider definitely
what its interests are. For instance, here
is a question.
Newspaper, Radio, AND Television?
Swamped by applications for TV chan¬
nels, the FCC has been making decisions
on licenses for channels for which there
was no contest. Now it will consider cases
in which two or more applicants want the
same channel.
Other things being approximately equal,
will it lease such a channel to applicants
owning a newspaper or a radio station or
both? Or to those not already possessed
of one or more means of mass communica¬
tions?
Different members of the Commission
within the last six months have given dif¬
ferent answers—1. that in such cases it fa¬
vored those with no radio station or news¬
paper: 2, that such ownership would make
no difference with the Commission’s deci¬
sions. It is not a question of absolute mon¬
opoly of opinion-forming facilities; for-one-
can subscribe to magazines and papers with
different opinions. The real question, one
we should consider most carefully, is this:
Will ownership of newspaper, radio and
television (perhaps the only newspaper, ra¬
dio and television in the area) determine at¬
titudes of the majority, so that the owners
of the mass media will, in effect control
elections, the passage of bills in legisla¬
tures, etc?
Frequency of Licensing
The FCC has decided, with one dissenting
vote, that the licenses of TV stations may
be renewed every three years (as with radio
stations) instead of every year, as has been
required for TV. The reasons given for the
change were time saved for the FCC and
trouble saved for the telecaster.
Commissioner Frieda B. Hennock gives
“the public interest" as her reason for dis¬
senting. For fourteen years, she explains,
radio stations were licensed every year, till,
in 1941 the Commission concluded, to quote
the FCC, that “the broadcasting industry has
reached a point of maturity where it ap¬
pears advisable to increase the license per¬
iod to two years.” In 1943 it was in¬
creased to three years. Commissioner Hen¬
nock points out that television is relatively
inexperienced. With more than 400 TV
stations licensed since the freeze (15 months)
the television industry has not attained ma¬
turity. Furthermore, the FCC has not had
the opportunity, in one year, to review the
station's, programming to determine whether
they are serving the public interest.
To quote the Commissioner, "My dis¬
agreement stems from the majority’s iden¬
tification of the ‘public interest’ with the
convenience of broadcast licensees, rather
than with higher public interest considera¬
tions.”
